PROGRAM PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
A.  Background and Justification 
1.  The Government of Azerbaijan is endeavoring to transform Azerbaijan Railways (ADY) 
into a profitable company and to improve railway service delivery. It has requested the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to finance (i) railway sector and corporate reforms and ADY financial 
restructuring; and (ii) improvements to railway infrastructure, particularly along the north-south 
railway  corridor.  This  program  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  will  prepare  (i)  a 
comprehensive policy matrix for the policy-based loan—covering institutional changes at ADY 
and in the railways sector, financial restructuring at ADY, a sector development plan, and other 
policy areas as needed—prepared in full consultation with all key railway stakeholders; (ii) a 
feasibility study for track renewal and a computerized freight operation system; and (iii) ADB 
loan processing documents, including a sector assessment; technical, economic, and financial 
appraisals; environmental, social, and poverty impact assessments; procurement preparation 
and project implementation arrangements. The government and ADY were advised that PPTA 
approval does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing project.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

a grant from ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF). The government, through ADY, 
will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, office space and supplies, secretarial 
assistance, and other in-kind contributions. Table A3.2 lists the detailed cost estimate.

5.  The program will have five outputs. The policy-based loan supports outputs 1–4, which 
cover  (i)  enhanced  management  autonomy  of  ADY  and  transport  sector  governance, 
(ii) effective financial restructuring of ADY's liabilities, (iii) enhanced financial and management 
control,  efficiency  and  reporting  at  ADY,  and  (iv)  business  development  and  corporate 
restructuring of ADY. The project loan supports Output 5, which includes rehabilitation of 441

km of single-track rail between Baku and Yalama, on the Russian border, and development of a

F.  Schedule and Reporting Requirements 
The  consulting  services  will  be  implemented  over  a  period  of  18  months,  beginning  
1 September 2016 and ending 1 March 2018. Technical assistance funds will be disbursed in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2015, as amended from 
time to time). The PPTA will be financially closed by 1 June 2018. The consultants will report 
directly to the project officer, unless responsibility for their supervision is delegated to ADY. The 
consultants will submit to ADY and ADB (i) an inception report 4 weeks after commencement of 
services; (ii) an interim report; and (iii) a final report 3 weeks after receipt of review comments 
from ADY and ADB. All reports will be written in English and translated into Azeri. Soft copies 
(.pdf and Word) of the inception, interim, and draft final reports (in English) will be submitted to 
ADB. One hard copy and one soft copy (.pdf) of each report (in both Azeri and English) will be 
submitted to ADY.
